comments.commentBody: and the failure to stop the Boston Marathon bombing; just substitute BPD for NYPD - the FBI and CIA don't discriminate when it decides with which local law enforcement agency it refuses to share intelligence....

A  "perception that the agency has exceeded its authorities" - you must be kidding, of course this was illegal domestic spying, and  this was not the first time.  Among other problems, this sort of poaching on the jurisdiction of the FBI was in part responsible for the failure of both agencies to follow the dots and stop 9/11.

Let's stay focused and continue to work together to mobilize ordinary people to vote. People on the center-left have to avoid wedge issues that the right-wing is always inserting in order to distract us. The center-left coalition held together from 1932 until the 1980s, but was gradually toppled by a well-organized movement on the right that planned carefully and executed their plans with great discipline.  We're on the path to retaking power in this country, but we have to constantly remember that we can't win all battles at once, and that not everyone agrees with us on every issue--indeed, we don't agree with each other on every issue. We need to win one battle after the other, and constantly maintain our solidarity with the larger project of creating a more fair and humane society.  Consigning the Republicans to the fringe of our political spectrum is doable. But please let's not again fall into the habit of demanding a perfect society right away, or allowing ego battles to separate us, or exploding into feel-good rants that split us into warring camps, or assuming that we don't need to convince (rather than force) people who disagree with us of many or our positions.  We went through that again and again from the 1960s on, and it didn't work. We're only a decade or so away from the goal of politically overthrowing the right-wing coalition, if we act widely.

CORRECTION:

We're only a decade or so away from the goal of politically overthrowing the right-wing coalition, if we act wisely.

Tough to say, and tough to hear, but there is a mean spirit abroad in this land, a swath of hatred that is a huge trough at which the Republican Party feeds.

If there were not "wedge" issues -- bigotry, prejudice, hatred, I-got-mine-ism, drown-the-government -- the Republicans would have not a leg to stand on.

Fortunately for them and devastating to the future of this country, they can sell what they're selling because there are more than enough people looking to get it.
Why did anyone vote the Republicans into power in the first place?

Or they'd have to put some money into it instead of having their hand out in Washington.

This bill is Corker's gift to his cronies in the Housing Industrial Complex.

Fannie and Freddie really are the ultimate 'lenders' for the majority of home buyers and those doing refinancing. Republicans are great at doing away with those things which they mistakenly perceive as a burden on society, when in fact a vibrant real estate market also brings buying of goods ranging from furniture, to carpeting, paint and all the accoutrements.

The construction industry went into a tailspin with this last Great Recession and is finally starting to revive.

Joe, you note that Fannie and Freddie are making gobs of money but somehow, to due to arcane provisions, these profits are not going toward 'repaying' the government for getting those agencies through the bad times. Wouldn't it make more sense to fix that flaw in the system rather than dismantling Freddie and Fannie?

Without these two titans, the real estate market and all those who depend on it for their livelihoods would come to a screeching halt.

I agree with Michael Wara.  The president is very tardy with his homework, and Obama's speech was very wishy-washy.  A tiny reduction by 2020 is just not good enough.  It should have been done before 1970.
Too funny el Greco - thanks for the chortle!
No, the Pats don't have to reinstate Hernandez in the unlikely case of being found innocent. I doubt they'd take him back in the case of such a possibility, despite his athletic talent.
Nope.  They can release any player, for no cause whatsoever.  It's not a legal issue.
No, his football days with the Pats are done.
If Hernandez is found to be innocent , will the Patriots have to reinstate him?

The Burkhauser study seems to include retirement assets in its tally of financial assets. The column author's four-paragraph quote from the study-team's reply to him mentions IRAs.
You're right about the DB-to-DC retirement shift, but a good deal of that probably predates the 1989 study start.
Still, let's not forget Mitt Romney's $102 million IRA. Hmmm, how did he pull that off, again? Mine's all the way up at $50K, after contributing the Ordinary-Joe maximum each and every year since IRAs started in 1974.

Do these data include assets held in retirement accounts? If so, the growth in inequality is significantly greater than what is being shown here. A generation ago, working and middle class people typically had defined benefit pension plans. The assets underlying these benefits would not show up on anybody's individual asset accounts. With the shift to defined contribution plans, these assets will now appear. However, the actual retirement income they will generate for most working and middle class people is significantly lower than what they would have received from the "old fashioned' defined benefit plans.

So working and middle class people are typically worse off as a result of this shift in retirement plans, but will appear better off using the measures being reported on here. This is clearly wrong.

I guess that would depend on who the other person is. I would think that most people would not hesitate to kill someone who was trying to kill them or one of their children.

Ben, Ben, read the article again, the whole thing, all the way through.  The motive as explained here doesn't make a lot of sense, but supposed motive is definitely discussed.
Yes.

Not going to take a position on gun control generally here but I think it's important to note that the biggest precursor to a violent crime here was a a person who thrived on being a thug. Thugs and guns don't mix, and unfortunately we have a nation full of thugs and a pop culture that idolizes that lifestyle to go along with all the guns.

Now you all know what teachers feel like when they are constantly evaluated by critics from afar. At least your critics are in the theater observing your efforts. Our critics don't even bother to come to our classrooms. However, they are perfectly happy to criticize our every effort based on hearsay and test scores.

So much for innovation and creativity....probably redundant.

We needs DNA tests on the Supreme Court to show how many are the descendants of slave owners. The hard-wired bigotry that would impel a person to be a slave owner is in the DNA. As Lincoln said "As I would not be a slave, nor would I be a master." That was Lincoln, and that capacity for empathy is a prerequisite for Democracy. The descendants of slave owners lack the DNA of empathy that Lincoln had ; they are genetically unfit for democracy.
Now, that is what I call ''living''

NYPD would rather go the the orchard and pick the fruit rather than go to the neighborhood FBI market and hope for the best. How would the NYPD know if they were getting it right if not gathering the intel themselves?  And NYPD has intel to share as every government of every relevant country and every irrelevant Banana Republic in the world is in New York City. The best organizations have a mixture of expertise and diversity.  Why shouldn't NYPD. Good Move.
New York is not a city state - I don't care what @Tim Lum says about picking better fruit. This is why Blommberg's NYPD is being sued for spying. Lawsuits cost the taxpayers unnecessarily in the end
Not only that, but they probably read all the comments to NYT articles like this and open files on all of us!

It's not just CIA officer involvement in NYPD that's a concern, but why does NYPD have foreign offices? NYPD has 2 offices in Israel in addition to officers stationed in London, Lyon, Hamburg and Toronto. King Bloomberg has created his own CIA/FBI/Police combo and Lord Kelly wants his very own drones to watch every move we make.
Tom Clancy.

Before that, don't you remember "Three Days of the Condor"?
It stared Robert Redford and the woman who stared in "Chinatown", another movie about how money makes it right.
We are now living with a seriously depleted lake in CA, thanks to the desire for water in Los Angeles.

It's really John Clancy's fault.  Government types read all his Jack Ryan stories and took them seriously.  It seems more and more like the only people with their feet on the ground are the ones who are trying to kill us.
Slave owners?  I'd love to find out that they're actually constructed of slave DNA.  Wonder if it would alter their thinking?

We need DNA tests on the Supreme Court to show how many are the descendants of slave owners. The hard-wired bigotry that would impel a person to be a slave owner is in the DNA. As Lincoln said "As I would not be a slave, nor would I be a master." That was Lincoln, and that capacity for empathy is a prerequisite for Democracy. The descendants of slave owners lack the DNA of empathy that Lincoln had ; they are genetically unfit for democracy.
Why not?  QUID is Brit slang for pound and established crosswordese.

See Bill's comments above. City consumers don't understand that our food supply is dependent on weather, quite beyond the control of government. A severe drought  caused cattle ranchers to cull their herds and caused a spike in corn prices (which feed cattle), with the result that cattle prices have been at record highs for the last three years (double what they were in 1998).

Self-control? That's a tall order in the face of the machine that manufactures these snack 'foods.'
The majority of snackers are people who have had the snack advertised to them. Corporate marketing depts and food engineers have designed this food to be irresistible yet eternally unsatisfying.
Corporate marketing has researched us to within two standard deviations. They have hired focus groups and found average people to "Take surveys at home for cash!" They know what marketing tactics push our primal lizard brain buttons of desire- whether sex, or fear of not fitting in, or fear of harm to self or family, activating a need that is hard to override.
They have hired supertasters to discern and eliminate any hint of taste and/or texture undesirability.
They have engineered the food to be the quickest to prepare, the most shelf-stable, and most appealing out of the box.

Self-control is sometimes a weak opponent of all these forces which have in many cases, cost hundreds of millions of dollars to invent.
The food industry is not the only one using these techniques on us. The corporate US capitalist economic structure* sells us everything based on feeling full instead of merely sated, in the name of profit.

*Capitalism doesn't have to be bad, but someday it will have to recognize the right of the individual to be healthy, provide for their families a minimum standard of living, and to have healthcare. It will eventually have to align with true democracy to survive.

Unfortunately, no way to tie in with ball clubs.
We also have some spitting going on at 43D.  I thought the NOSE clue was funny, if a tad icky.

Yes, Nina R-M, We can do very nicely sans the SPAT, especially if we expectorate with the other XWDP blogs on line!

Howie

I thought the theme was rather thin for a Thursday, just a few inches short of clever. I expected more of a twist to it. The fill was on the easy side, again considering the day of the week.

I guess Mr. Dobbin really wanted to avoid ETTU and BEETLE at all costs, so we have ATTU and BEATLE instead. Great clue for the Fab Four though. I also had adages before AXIOMS.

ALLISWELL could've been a contender for a theme answer except for the double-L: "Muhammad's water source?"

BATSMAN obviously fits the baseball theme, as does SPAT OUT.

Strangely, stud muffin never once occurred to me until I read Deb's funny writeup. I guess solving on an empty stomach worked in my favor. I had corn or BRAN in mind from the beginning -- and maybe some cheesecake.

Will, does NOSE picking meet the breakfast table TEST? Not in my household.

Rights protected by the courts but not by the popular will as expressed by the ballot will always be under attack by opportunistic politicians.  A sharply divided electorate also spells trouble.  Roe v. Wade may crumble; we have to win this battle for women's rights state by state.
